The role of the intraocular lens in postoperative cataract surgery.
The purpose of this study was to evaluate the role of intraocular lens (IOL) in postoperative cataract surgery. A cadaveric eye was used; the lens was implanted in the anterior chamber of the eye. Rectal irrigation was administered to the left eye. The eye was placed in a fixed position; the lens was fixed with an acrylic adapter. The lens was screwed onto a rubber ring and allowed to dry for about 30 minutes. The lens was removed at the same time. After the lens was removed, the vitreous with the lens was removed. The lens was fixed with an acrylic adapter. After removal, the lens was used for postoperative cataract surgery. The amount of wound infection, microscopy, and that of postoperative pain were calculated. The intraocular lens was the most commonly used lens in this study. Wound infection was observed in 42.9% of the cases. The most common intraoperative complication was infection in 10% of the cases. The most common complication was wound infection in 14.7% of the cases. The most common postoperative complication was wound infection in 10.4% of the cases. The remaining complication was thrombotic complications in 5.9% of the cases. The intraocular lens was the most commonly used lens in this study.
